basics.name: Dennis Hartmann
basics.position: Research asisstant in quantum graivty and experimental XRay detectors
basics.summary: Mexican-born German (recently American) physics student interested in the quantum nature of gravity and working in the Penn State XRay detector astronomy lab

Research Positions.name: Institute for Gravitation and the Cosmos, Penn State University
Research Positions.position: PostBac Research assistant for Dr. Martin Bojowald
Research Positions.summary: Studying various approaches to quantum gravity such as causal dynamical triangulations (CDT), asymptotic safety, and studies of the covariance of models from loop quantum gravity (LQG)
highlights: Emergent Modified Gravity, CDT, Asymptotic Safety, LQG, LQC

Research Positions.name: Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Penn State University
Research Positions.position: PostBac Research assistant for Dr. Abe Falcone
Research Positions.summary: Various laboratory projects to aid in the calibration and characterization of XRay Hybrid CMOS detectors to be used for the NASA BlackCAT Mission
highlights: HCDS, Hybrid CMOS Detectors, NASA, BlackCAT, AGN

Research Positions.name: Institute for Gravitation and the Cosmos, Penn State University
Research Positions.position: Undergraduate Research assistant for Dr. Martin Bojowald
Research Positions.summary: Studied the emergent modified gravity (EMG) and how it can be used to study signature changes in the metric, and effect that should be present in loop quantum gravity, but possible on universal scale as proposed in our paper. Further studied casusal dynamical triangulations (CDT) using a Lorentzian signature
highlights: Emergent Modified Gravity, CDT, LQG, LQC

Research Positions.name: Institute for Gravitation and the Cosmos, Penn State University
Research Positions.position: Undergraduate Research assistant for Dr. Jackson Henry and Dr. Sarah Shandera
Research Positions.summary: Characterized the interactions between qubits in thermalizing open quantum systems by understanding properties such as their connectivities

Research Positions.name: University of Pennsylvania
Research Positions.position: NSF REU student for Dr. Andrea Liu

Research Positions.name: Department of Mathematics, Penn State University
Research Positions.position: Undergraduate Research assistant for Dr. Toan Nguyen
highlights: Quantum Many Body Systems, Hamiltonian Dynamics

volunteering.organization: President of the Society of Physics Students (SPS)
volunteering.summary: Leader of the Penn State Chapter of the SPS, a national organization charged with providing a home for undergaduate physics majors. Led a team of 5 other officers, interacted with both the leadership of the physics department and the large membership of SPS.

volunteering.organization: Outreach Officer of the Society of Physics Students (SPS)
volunteering.summary: In charge of outreach activities for SPS such as local school visits.

volunteering.organization: APS Inclusion, Diversity, and Equity Alliance (IDEA)
volunteering.summary: Part of Penn State's IDEA team, which discussed issues of DEI at Penn State and interacted with the broader IDEA network at other institutions. As the IDEA team was a part of the Climate and Inclusivity committee, the insights would get passed on to them.
In charge of outreach activities for SPS such as local school visits.
In charge of outreach activities for PAW+ such as Haunted-U.

awards.title: David Bohm Award
awards.summary: The David Bohm Award recognizes “…a graduating senior Physics major who has excelled academically and who has made contributions to Penn State outside the classroom in areas such as research or service to Penn State at the department, College, or University level.”'

awards.title: Langhorne Brickwedde Award for Undergraduate Research
awards.summary: The Langhorne Brickwedde Award for Undergraduate Research was established by “friends, colleagues, and the family in honor of Langhorne H. Brickwedde, a member of the College of Science faculty from January 1, 1967, until her retirement July 1, 1974.'

awards.title: M. Dean and Jean L. Underwood Scholarship in Physics
George E., Jr. and Elizabeth S. Sperling Tutorial Endowment in Calculus, Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics
Eberly College of Science Internal Scholarship
M. Dean and Jean L. Underwood Scholarship in Physics

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
